questions.text: Which of the following is the Information Communication Technology based Surveillance system for TB patients under National TB Elimination Program? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nikshay

 

Nikshay is an online software platform used in India for the surveillance of tuberculosis (TB) patients under the National TB Elimination Program. This Information and Communication Technology (ICT)-based system connects all the DOTS (Directly Observed Treatment, Short-course) clinics across the country to a central server managed by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare. It allows for real-time data generation and monitoring, providing critical insights into cure rates, incidences of multi-drug-resistant TB (MDR-TB), treatment failures, relapses, and other important metrics. The system's comprehensive data collection capabilities make it an essential tool in the fight against TB.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DOTS: DOTS (Directly Observed Treatment, Short-course) is a strategy rather than a surveillance system. It involves healthcare workers observing patients take their TB medication to ensure compliance, but it is not a technological platform like Nikshay.

 

Option B. DOTS-99: DOTS-99 is an ICT-based adherence system, not a surveillance system. It is designed to ensure patients adhere to their TB treatment regimen. After taking their medication, patients give a missed call to a toll-free number using their registered mobile number. This system is effective in tracking medication adherence but does not provide the comprehensive surveillance and data management features of Nikshay.

 

Option D. Nischay: "Nischay" is not related to TB surveillance or management. This option does not pertain to any ICT-based system for TB patients under the National TB Elimination Program.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nikshay is the ICT-based surveillance system used for TB patients under the National TB Elimination Program in India. It enables real-time data collection and monitoring of TB cases across the country.

questions.text: The time gap between entry of organism in human body and its maximal infectivity is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Generation time

 

Generation time is defined as the time interval between the entry of an infectious organism into the human body and the period when the individual reaches maximal infectivity. This concept is crucial in understanding the spread of infectious diseases, as it indicates when an infected person is most likely to transmit the infection to others.

 

Generation time helps public health professionals predict the spread of disease and is essential in planning control measures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incubation period: This option is incorrect. The incubation period is the time from exposure to the onset of first sign/symptom, not specifically related to the peak of infectivity.

 

Option B. Median IP: This option is incorrect. Median incubation period refers to the time by which 50% of cases exhibit symptoms, unrelated to infectivity.

 

Option C.  Serial IP (Serial Interval Period): This option is incorrect. The serial interval measures the gap between symptom onset in a primary case and a secondary case, not between entry of the organism and peak infectivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Generation time is the interval between the entry of an organism into the body and the point of maximal infectivity.

questions.text: A 27-year-old patient was found to have uterus didelphys. Which of the following is not likely to be a complication of this uterine anomaly? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endometriosis

 

Endometriosis: Endometriosis can occur in patients with uterus didelphys, particularly in the rare variant known as OHVIRA syndrome (Obstructed Hemi Vagina with Ipsilateral Renal Agenesis), where menstrual blood can become trapped, leading to retrograde menstruation and endometriosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abortion: Spontaneous abortion is a potential complication associated with uterus didelphys due to the structural anomaly affecting the uterine environment.

 

Option C. Preterm labor: Preterm labor is a recognized complication in patients with uterus didelphys. The abnormal structure of the uterus can lead to difficulties in carrying the pregnancy to full term.

 

Option D. Transverse lie: Among the given options, transverse lie is not a likely complication of uterus didelphys. A transverse lie is more commonly associated with an arcuate or sub-septate uterus, rather than uterus didelphys. Uterus didelphys usually has a better reproductive outcome compared to other uterine anomalies, though it still presents with certain risks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uterus didelphys is associated with complications such as spontaneous abortion, preterm labor, and endometriosis, but it is less likely to cause a transverse lie, which is more common in arcuate or sub-septate uteri.

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7231278/

choices.text: Check shunt patency by nuclear study
Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap
Blood culture and take CSF sample by lumbar puncture

questions.text: A young child with congenital hydrocephalus was treated with a successful ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt. Four months post surgical repair, the child presented with fever, nuchal rigidity, and irritability. You suspect meningitis. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap

 

The most appropriate next step for a child with a VP shunt who presents with symptoms suspicious for meningitis is to obtain blood cultures and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) samples from the shunt tap and/or lumbar puncture. It is important to diagnose and treat meningitis quickly in patients with VP shunts, as untreated meningitis can cause shunt malfunction and other complications.

 

The diagnosis of meningitis in a child with a VP shunt requires obtaining blood cultures and CSF samples. Blood cultures are needed to identify the causative organism, while CSF samples are used to confirm the diagnosis and determine the severity of the infection. CSF can be obtained either through a shunt tap or a lumbar puncture, depending on the child's clinical status and the availability of the appropriate resources.

 

VP shunt fluid is usually obtained from a reservoir that is easily accessible subcutaneously. After sterile preparation, the reservoir should be punctured with a 25-gauge needle. The risk of introducing infection is also low (4.1%).

 

 

Ventriculoperitoneal shunt:

 

 

A ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt is used to drain excess cerebrospinal fluid (CS) due to an obstruction in the normal outflow or there is a decreased absorption of the fluid.

 

Complications of the shunting procedure include the following:

 

  • Infection due to skin flora entering the shunt, usually from Staphylococcus epidermidis
  • Intracerebral or intraventricular hemorrhage
  • Shunt over drainage (slit ventricles)
  • Shunt nephritis
  • Shunt disconnection
  • Shunt obstruction
  • Inguinal hernia

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wait and watch: as the patient is showing features of complication, wait and watch will not be the appropriate answer.

 

Option B. Check shunt patency by nuclear study: we should check the patency of the shunt but as the patient is showing signs of meningitis we should do a CSF analysis by shunt tap.

 

Option C. Blood culture and take CSF sample by lumbar puncture: the main source of infection is from the shunt, so taking CSF sample from there is best.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best step for a child with a VP shunt showing signs of meningitis is to perform a blood culture and obtain a CSF sample from the shunt tap.

choices.text: C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers
A fibers are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibers
A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers
A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibers

questions.text: A person after sleeping overnight with the arm under his head now experiences paresis but no numbness in the morning. Which of the following is the best explanation for it?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers

 

Explanation

 

In the above scenario, the patient has developed paresis (partial paralysis) but the pain sensation is intact (no numbness) suggests A fibers involvement as they carry motor, touch, and pressure sensations are most sensitive to pressure changes/compression.

 

A fibers are myelinated nerve fibers responsible for transmitting signals related to touch, pressure, and proprioception (the sense of one's body position). C fibers, on the other hand, are unmyelinated and transmit slower pain signals. While both types of fibers can be affected by pressure, A fibers are more vulnerable to damage from sustained pressure than C fibers, which are more resistant to compression.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers. - Incorrect. C fibers are unmyelinated and relatively more resistant to pressure compared to myelinated A fibers.

 

Option B. A fibers are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibers. - Not relevant to the scenario, as the issue is related to mechanical pressure, not oxygen deprivation.

 

Option D. A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibers. - Also not relevant to the given scenario, focusing on hypoxia instead of the impact of mechanical pressure or compression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Relative susceptibility -

questions.text: A child presents to the emergency department with a history of ingestion of 10-20 ferrous sulfate tablets. Arterial blood gas revealed acidosis. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Deferoxamine

 

Iron overdose, particularly with ferrous sulfate tablets, can lead to severe toxicity. Ingesting more than 60 mg/kg of elemental iron is considered potentially lethal. Acute iron poisoning presents with gastrointestinal symptoms initially and can progress to metabolic acidosis, shock, and multi-organ failure.

 

The presence of acidosis on arterial blood gas analysis is an important indicator of severe iron toxicity and an indication for the administration of an antidote. The appropriate antidote for acute iron intoxication is deferoxamine. Deferoxamine chelates free iron, forming a water-soluble complex that is excreted in the urine, thereby reducing iron's toxic effects on the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Activated charcoal: Activated charcoal is not effective in cases of iron poisoning. It does not adsorb metals like iron and can be harmful in certain situations like heavy metal poisoning, alcohols, petroleum products, and caustic substances.

 

Option C. Dimercaprol: Dimercaprol is used for chelation therapy in heavy metal poisoning (e.g., arsenic, mercury, gold) but is not effective for iron poisoning.

 

Option D. Penicillamine: Penicillamine is another chelating agent, typically used for conditions such as Wilson's disease (copper overload) and rheumatoid arthritis. It is not effective in treating iron toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of acute iron intoxication with signs of toxicity such as acidosis, the antidote of choice is deferoxamine. Activated charcoal is not effective in iron poisoning and should not be used.

questions.text: An 18-month-old baby presents with vesicles on the anterior abdominal wall and forearm, as well as meningitis. A Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells. The mother has a history of genital lesions. What is the likely diagnosis, and what is the causative agent? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HSV 2

 

In this scenario, the 18-month-old baby presents with vesicles on the anterior abdominal wall and forearm, as well as meningitis. The Tzanck smear shows multinucleate giant cells, which are indicative of a herpes virus infection. Given the mother’s history of genital lesions, it is highly suggestive that the baby contracted the infection during delivery.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Vesicles: The presence of vesicles (fluid-filled blisters) is characteristic of herpes infections.
  • Tzanck Smear: This test shows multinucleate giant cells, which are typical findings in herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections.
  • Mother's Genital Lesions: This detail strongly indicates genital herpes, which is most commonly caused by HSV-2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Varicella Zoster: Although varicella zoster virus (VZV) can cause vesicles and multinucleate giant cells, the history of maternal genital lesions and the clinical presentation points more specifically towards HSV.

 

Option C. Enterococcus: This bacterium is not associated with vesicular lesions or multinucleate giant cells on Tzanck smear. It typically causes urinary tract infections, bacteremia, and endocarditis, not the described symptoms.

 

Option D. Toxoplasmosis: Toxoplasmosis can cause congenital infections but does not present with vesicular skin lesions or multinucleate giant cells. The typical findings include intracranial calcifications, chorioretinitis, and hydrocephalus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HSV-2 is a common cause of neonatal herpes, which presents with vesicular lesions and can be confirmed with a Tzanck smear showing multinucleate giant cells. Maternal genital herpes is a significant risk factor for neonatal transmission.

questions.text: An elderly woman reports difficulty in buttoning her shirt and increased clumsiness in performing daily activities. On examination, the clinician asked her to make an 'O' using her thumb and index finger, which she was unable to do. Which of the following muscles is involved? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flexor pollicis longus

 

The inability to form an 'O' using the thumb and index finger suggests a problem with muscles that control flexion of these digits, specifically the flexor pollicis longus, which is responsible for flexing the thumb at the distal phalanx. This muscle is innervated by the anterior interosseous nerve, a branch of the median nerve. The condition described in the question is consistent with anterior interosseous nerve syndrome, which impairs the flexion of the distal phalanges of the thumb and index finger, making it difficult to perform tasks requiring precise pinch or grip, such as buttoning a shirt.

 

In Anterior interosseous nerve syndrome flexor pollicis longus and flexor digitorum profundus are affected.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palmar interossei: These muscles are primarily involved in the adduction of the fingers (PAD - Palmar Adducts), and they do not play a role in flexing the thumb or index finger. Therefore, they are not related to the inability to form an 'O'.

 

Option B. Opponens pollicis: This muscle is involved in the opposition of the thumb, allowing the thumb to touch the other fingers. It is not directly responsible for flexion of the thumb or index finger and is innervated by the lateral terminal branch of the median nerve. Its dysfunction would affect opposition rather than the ability to form an 'O'.

 

Note an update - Opponens pollicis, a hybrid muscle, as innervated by the lateral terminal branch of the median nerve, and commonly by a branch of the deep terminal branch of the ulnar nerve.

 

Option D. Abductor pollicis brevis: This muscle is responsible for the abduction of the thumb, moving it away from the palm. It does not contribute to flexing the thumb at the distal phalanx, which is necessary to form an 'O'. Thus, its involvement does not explain the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior interosseous nerve syndrome affects the flexor pollicis longus and flexor digitorum profundus muscles, leading to difficulty in forming an 'O' with the thumb and index finger due to impaired flexion.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with heart failure and poorly controlled type 2 diabetes (HbA1c of 7.8%) presents with progressive dyspnea. Which is the preferred antidiabetic drug? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dapagliflozin

 

Dapagliflozin is a sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitor that has shown significant benefits in patients with heart failure, particularly heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). SGLT2 inhibitors, including dapagliflozin and empagliflozin, have been demonstrated to improve survival, reduce heart failure hospitalizations, and delay the progression of heart failure. These benefits make SGLT2 inhibitors the preferred choice for patients with both type 2 diabetes and heart failure.

 

Four Pillars in the Management of HFrEF (Heart Failure with Reduced Ejection Fraction):

 

  1. ARNIs and ACE Inhibitors/ARBs:
    • ARNIs (e.g., Sacubitril/Valsartan) are preferred.
    • ACE Inhibitors/ARBs are also used.
  2. Beta Blockers:
    • Metoprolol
    • Bisoprolol
    • Carvedilol
  3. MRAs (Mineralocorticoid Receptor Antagonists):
    • Spironolactone
    • Eplerenone
  4. SGLT2 Inhibitors:
    • Empagliflozin
    • Dapagliflozin

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glimepiride: This is a sulfonylurea that primarily helps in lowering blood glucose by stimulating insulin secretion. It does not provide the cardiovascular benefits seen with SGLT2 inhibitors and can increase the risk of hypoglycemia.

 

Option C. Metformin: While metformin is a first-line therapy for type 2 diabetes and has some cardiovascular benefits, it is not specifically indicated for improving heart failure outcomes.

 

Option D. Sitagliptin: This is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor used to manage blood glucose levels. It does not provide the same level of heart failure benefit as SGLT2 inhibitors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with type 2 diabetes and heart failure, SGLT2 inhibitors like dapagliflozin are the preferred antidiabetic medications due to their proven benefits in reducing heart failure progression, hospitalizations, and mortality.

questions.text: A female patient with infertility presents with galactorrhea. Evaluation reveals a 7mm prolactinoma. She is worried about her conception chances. What is the appropriate drug in this situation? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bromocriptine

 

Explanation:

 

The choice of dopamine agonist therapy for hyperprolactinemia in patients desiring fertility remains somewhat controversial. Advanced textbooks such as "Speroff's Clinical Gynecologic Endocrinology and Infertility" clearly highlight that cabergoline has greater potency, fewer side effects, better tolerability, and convenient dosing compared to bromocriptine, leading to its general preference for prolactinoma treatment.

 

However, Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine (21st Edition) explicitly mentions:

 

“Because cabergoline is long-acting with a high D₂-receptor affinity, it is not recommended for use in women when fertility is desired.”

 

Considering the context of Indian postgraduate entrance examinations, it is advisable to adhere to Harrison's recommendations. Therefore, although cabergoline is generally considered superior, bromocriptine is the safer and recommended answer for this specific examination scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cabergoline: Although generally preferred for routine prolactinoma management, it is explicitly not recommended during conception planning as per Harrison’s.

 

Option C. Octreotide: A somatostatin analog indicated exclusively for GH-secreting tumors, not prolactinoma.

 

Option D. Pegvisomant: A GH receptor antagonist used specifically in acromegaly, with no role in prolactinoma or fertility management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For Indian PG entrance examinations, bromocriptine remains the recommended first-line treatment in women with microprolactinoma who desire fertility, despite cabergoline’s clinical advantages, based on guidelines explicitly mentioned in Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine.

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented with weight gain and hyperpigmentation of palms and soles. He was subsequently diagnosed to have lung cancer. Which of the following is responsible for hyperpigmentation? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Melanocyte Stimulating Hormone (MSH)

 

Explanation:

 

The patient, a chronic smoker, presented with weight gain and hyperpigmentation of the palms and soles and was diagnosed with lung cancer. This clinical scenario suggests the presence of an ectopic ACTH-producing tumor, most commonly associated with small cell lung cancer.

 

In such cases, the excessive ACTH produced by the tumor can lead to Cushing's syndrome.

 

Additionally, ACTH has an intrinsic MSH (Melanocyte Stimulating Hormone) activity due to the shared precursor molecule, proopiomelanocortin (POMC). The MSH part within ACTH stimulates melanocytes, leading to increased melanin production and resulting in hyperpigmentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemosiderin: Hemosiderin is an iron-storage complex. It does not play a role in causing hyperpigmentation in this context.

 

Option C. Neuropeptide Y: Neuropeptide Y is involved in various physiological processes, including regulation of appetite and stress responses, but not in causing hyperpigmentation.

 

Option D. Melanin: While melanin is the pigment responsible for skin color, its production is stimulated by MSH. Thus, MSH is the direct cause of increased melanin and subsequent hyperpigmentation in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of ectopic ACTH production, such as with small cell lung cancer, hyperpigmentation occurs due to the MSH activity of ACTH, which stimulates melanocytes to produce melanin.

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of trauma and the following radiological image. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blow Out Fracture

 

Explanation: 

 

A blow out fracture is characterized by:

 

  • Tear drop sign on radiological imaging
  • Fracture of the orbital floor
  • Herniation of contents into the maxillary sinus
  • Typically results from blunt trauma

 

Clinical findings include:

 

  • Restriction of upward gaze
  • Diplopia in up gaze
  • Decreased sensation in infraorbital cheek area
  • Potential enophthalmos (sunken eye)

 

Diagnostic confirmation is done through:

 

  • Forced duction test (FDT) to differentiate restrictive from paralytic pathology

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Orbital Lateral Wall Fracture : Incorrect. Does not match the characteristic tear drop sign of floor fracture.

 

Option B. Orbital Medial Wall Fracture : Incorrect. Location does not correspond to the radiological findings.

 

Option D. Orbital Cellulitis : Incorrect. This is an inflammatory condition, not a traumatic fracture.

 

Educational Objective: 


Recognize the radiological tear drop sign as a key indicator of an orbital floor blow out fracture following blunt trauma.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles functions as a tensor of the vocal cords? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cricothyroid

 

Cricothyroid is a tensor of vocal cord.

 

The cricothyroid muscle is primarily responsible for lengthening and tensing the vocal cords. When this muscle contracts, it pulls the thyroid cartilage forward and down towards the cricoid cartilage, which results in elongation and tensioning of the vocal cords. This action increases the pitch of the voice. Because of its role in tensioning the vocal cords, the cricothyroid is sometimes referred to as a tensor of the vocal cords.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lateral cricoarytenoid: The lateral cricoarytenoid muscles are responsible for adducting the vocal cords. When these muscles contract, they rotate the arytenoid cartilages medially, which causes the vocal cords to come together. This action is crucial for phonation (production of sound), as the vocal cords must be close together to vibrate against each other. However, the lateral cricoarytenoids do not play a direct role in the tensioning or relaxation of the vocal cords.

 

Option C. Thyroarytenoids: The thyroarytenoids are the primary muscles within the vocal cords themselves. They have two parts: the thyrovocalis (medial) and the thyromuscularis (lateral). The thyrovocalis is involved in the shortening and tensioning of the vocal cords, leading to a decrease in pitch. In contrast, the thyromuscularis aids in relaxing and thickening the cords, which lowers the pitch. Together, they play a critical role in controlling pitch and the quality of the voice.

 

Option D. Posterior cricoarytenoids: The posterior cricoarytenoid muscles are the primary muscles responsible for abducting or opening the vocal cords. They rotate the arytenoid cartilages laterally, which pulls the vocal cords apart. This action is vital for breathing, as the vocal cords must be open for air to flow into the lungs.

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Factors II, VII, IX, and X

questions.text: Which of the following zymogens requires gamma-glutamyl carboxylase? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factors II, VII, IX, and X

 

Clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X are zymogens of serine proteases that contain glutamic acid residues. These residues undergo vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation via gamma-glutamyl carboxylase to form gamma-carboxy glutamic acid residues. This enables them to bind calcium ions (Ca2+), which is necessary for their activation and subsequent blood clot formation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factors II, VIII, IX, X: Factor VIII is not a zymogen that requires gamma-glutamyl carboxylase. It is involved in the intrinsic pathway of coagulation but does not undergo vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation.

 

Option C. Factors II, VII, IX, XI: Factor XI is not a zymogen that requires gamma-glutamyl carboxylase. It is activated by thrombin and does not undergo vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation.

 

Option D. Factors II, VIII, X, XI: Neither Factor VIII nor Factor XI are zymogens that require gamma-glutamyl carboxylase. They do not undergo vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zymogens are the proprotein form of enzymes (proenzymes) that require proteolytic activation to carry out their function.

 

Inactive form of vitamin K acts as a cofactor in the post-synthetic modification of these zymogens and their activation. This inactive form of vitamin K is recycled back from its oxidized form by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase, which can be inhibited by warfarin or liver failure.

choices.text: Linezolid: Binds to 30S ribosome and inhibits protein synthesis.

questions.text: Concerning the mechanism of action of various antimicrobial drugs, which of the following statements is FALSE?  (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Linezolid: Binds to 30S ribosome and inhibits protein synthesis.

 

Linezolid is an oxazolidinone antibiotic that actually binds to the 50S subunit of bacterial ribosomes, not the 30S subunit. Its mechanism of action involves the inhibition of protein synthesis by preventing the formation of a functional 70S initiation complex, which is essential for bacterial translation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rifampicin: is indeed known to inhibit DNA-dependent RNA polymerase, which is critical for RNA synthesis in bacteria.

 

Option C. Aztreonam: is a monobactam antibiotic that inhibits cell wall synthesis by binding to penicillin-binding proteins, thereby inhibiting peptidoglycan synthesis.

 

Option D. Daptomycin: causes depolarization of bacterial cell membranes, leading to the inhibition of all intracellular synthesis, including protein, DNA, and RNA synthesis, and ultimately cell death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Linezolid binds to the 50S subunit of bacterial ribosomes, not the 30S subunit, making the statement that it binds to the 30S subunit and inhibits protein synthesis false. The other drugs mentioned have their mechanisms correctly stated.

questions.text: Vitamin A deficiency is characteristic of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bitot spots

 

Bitot spots are a characteristic sign of vitamin A deficiency. They appear as dry, foamy, triangular patches on the conjunctiva, typically on the temporal side of the cornea. These spots are part of a condition called xerophthalmia, which is dryness of the eye due to vitamin A deficiency. Bitot spots represent a more advanced stage of xerophthalmia, classified as stage X1B in the WHO classification of vitamin A deficiency.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stocker's line: This is an iron deposition line seen in front of a pterygium. It is not related to vitamin A deficiency.

 

 

Option B. Pinguecula: This is a yellowish, raised lesion on the conjunctiva near the corneal limbus. It's caused by elastotic degeneration due to prolonged UV exposure, not vitamin A deficiency.

 

 

Option C. Pterygium: This is a wing-shaped growth of conjunctiva extending onto the cornea. Like pinguecula, it's associated with UV exposure and not vitamin A deficiency.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bitot spots are a characteristic sign of vitamin A deficiency, appearing as dry, foamy patches on the conjunctiva and representing stage X1B of xerophthalmia.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with growth on talus as seen on foot x-ray. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteochondroma

 

  • Osteochondroma is a common benign bone tumor that typically presents as a growth on the bone with a cartilage cap. 
  • In this case, the boy has a growth on the talus, which is characteristic of osteochondroma.
  • X-ray Findings: On x-ray, osteochondroma appears as a bone growth projecting from the surface, often with a cartilaginous cap that is not visible on the x-ray itself since cartilage is radiolucent.
  • Presentation: Patients often notice a palpable mass, which feels larger than what is seen on the x-ray due to the cartilage component (as radiolucent).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enchondroma: This is a benign cartilaginous tumor that occurs inside the bone (endosteal). It is more common in small bones of the hands and feet and does not present as an external growth.

 

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma: This is a malignant bone tumor typically found in the metaphyses of long bones, such as around the knee. It presents as a destructive bone lesion with a periosteal reaction, often not seen in the talus.

 

 

Option C. Osteomyelitis: This is an infection of the bone that leads to inflammation. It usually shows a solid periosteal reaction or lytic cavities on x-ray and does not present as a growth. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given x-ray image shows growth in the talus which is characteristic of osteochondroma of the talus bone. 
  • Osteochondroma is a benign bone tumor presenting as a palpable growth with a cartilaginous cap, most often found in young adults, and visible on x-ray as a bony projection.

questions.text: Which of the following is not classified as a germ cell tumor of the ovary? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Granulosa cell tumor

 

Granulosa cell tumor is a sex cord-stromal tumor, not a germ cell tumor of the ovary.

 

Granulosa cell tumors are derived from the sex cord-stromal cells of the ovary. These tumors are characterized by the presence of Call-Exner bodies and coffee bean-shaped nuclei. They are estrogen-secreting functional tumors that may present as precocious puberty, endometrial hyperplasia, or post-menopausal bleeding. The marker for granulosa cell tumors is Inhibin B, and they are associated with FOXL2 mutation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Yolk sac tumor: This is incorrect because yolk sac tumor, also known as endodermal sinus tumor, is a germ cell tumor of the ovary. 

 

Yolk sac tumor (Endodermal sinus tumor)

 

  • 2nd MC malignant GCT
  • MC malignant ovarian tumor presenting in <4years
  • Histology: presence of Schiller Duval Body/Glomeruloid body
  • Tumor markers: AFP +, α1 AT +ve

 

 

Option B. Dysgerminoma: This is incorrect because dysgerminoma is a germ cell tumor of the ovary. It is the ovarian counterpart of testicular seminoma. 

  • Ovarian counterpart of seminoma
  • MC malignant GCT
  • Radiosensitive, chemo-sensitive tumor
  • Unilateral involvement mostly (85%)
  • Non-Functional tumor: hormones not secreted
  • Markers include transcription factors (OCT 3/4, NANOG, KiT) and enzymes (PLAP +, LDH, ß HCG but Normal AFP)

 

Option C. Choriocarcinoma: This is incorrect because choriocarcinoma can coexist with other germ cell tumors, as it can arise from either the ovary (germ cell origin) or the placenta (gestational trophoblastic disease)

 

  • It secretes beta-hCG, which serves as a tumor marker.
  • If it has ovarian origin: non- responsive to chemotherapy → poor prognosis 
  • If it has placenta origin excellent responsive to chemotherapy → good prognosis
  • Choriocarcinoma is known for early hematogenous spread and "cannon-ball" metastases to the lungs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granulosa cell tumor is classified as a sex cord-stromal tumor of the ovary, not a germ cell tumor.

questions.text: A patient with a history of smoking presents with a cough and hemoptysis. A chest X-ray is done and it is shown below. Which of the following findings is least likely to be associated with this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Exophthalmos

 

Explanation:

 

The X-ray findings suggest a Pancoast tumor (superior sulcus tumor), which can invade adjacent structures, causing:

 

  • Brachial plexopathy (compression of lower brachial plexus)
  • Horner’s syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis) due to sympathetic chain involvement
  • Superior vena cava syndrome due to compression of the superior vena cava

 

Exophthalmos is more commonly associated with Graves’ disease and is not a feature of Pancoast tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Horner syndrome: Incorrect because this is a common finding in Pancoast tumor due to involvement of the sympathetic chain

 

Option B. Brachial plexopathy: Incorrect because this is commonly seen due to compression of the lower part of the brachial plexus by the tumor

 

Option C. Superior vena cava syndrome: Incorrect because SVC syndrome can occur in Pancoast tumors due to compression or invasion of the superior vena cava

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pancoast tumors present with Horner’s syndrome, brachial plexopathy, and superior vena cava syndrome, but exophthalmos is not part of the presentation.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by the vector shown below? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Orientia

 

Explanation:

 

Orientia, the causative agent of scrub typhus, is transmitted by chigger mites, not by the tick shown in the image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Babesia: Transmitted by ticks

 

Option C. Ehrlichia: Also transmitted by ticks

 

Option D. Crimean congo hemorrhagic fever : Also transmitted by ticks

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orientia tsutsugamushi, responsible for scrub typhus, is not transmitted by ticks but by chigger mites, distinguishing it from other tick-borne infections like Babesia and Ehrlichia.

questions.text: B-cells are induced to produce IgE by which of the following: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IL-4

 

IL-4 stimulates B-cells to differentiate into IgE secreting plasma cells.

 

IL-4 is a cytokine that plays a crucial role in promoting B-cell differentiation and class switching to produce IgE antibodies. It is primarily produced by T-helper 2 (Th2) cells and stimulates B-cells to undergo isotype switching, leading to the production of IgE instead of other antibody isotypes, such as IgG or IgM.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IL-2:

 

Role: IL-2 is crucial for T-cell proliferation, survival, and activation. It is not directly involved in the induction of IgE production by B-cells.

 

Option C. IL-1:

 

Role: IL-1 is involved in inflammation and immune responses, acting as a pro-inflammatory cytokine. It does not directly induce IgE production.

 

Option D. IL-6:

 

Role: IL-6 is important for inflammation, immune responses, and hematopoiesis. It has roles in the differentiation of B-cells into plasma cells, but it does not specifically induce IgE production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IL-4 is the key cytokine that stimulates B-cells to differentiate into IgE-secreting plasma cells, playing a crucial role in the allergic response and defense against parasites.

questions.text: Which type of PCR is suitable for identifying multiple causative agents? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Multiplex PCR    

 

Multiplex PCR is a technique that allows the simultaneous amplification of multiple target sequences in a single PCR reaction. This makes it particularly useful for identifying multiple causative agents in a single test, such as when diagnosing conditions like diarrhea that can be caused by a variety of pathogens including viruses, bacteria, and fungi. Multiplex PCR uses multiple sets of primers in a single reaction mixture, each specific for a different target, allowing the detection of multiple organisms in one run.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conventional PCR: This method involves amplifying a single DNA target per reaction and is not designed to handle multiple targets simultaneously, making it less suitable for identifying multiple causative agents.

 

Option B. Real-time PCR: While real-time PCR can quantify DNA or RNA targets and is highly sensitive, it typically amplifies one target per reaction or a few targets in separate reactions rather than multiple agents in a single test.

 

Option D. Nested PCR: This technique is designed to increase the specificity of PCR by using two sets of primers in two successive runs, but it is not intended for simultaneous detection of multiple pathogens. It is primarily used to reduce non-specific binding and enhance detection sensitivity for a specific target.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiplex PCR is the best choice for identifying multiple causative agents in a single test, making it efficient and comprehensive for diagnosing conditions caused by various pathogens.

questions.text:
PQLI indicators include: [NEET PG 2024]

 

  1. Literacy rate
  2. Infant mortality rate
  3. Life expectancy at birth
  4. Income per capita
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Only two of these

 

The Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) is a measure used to assess the quality of life in different countries. It focuses on three main indicators: health, education, and living standards. Specifically, these indicators include:

 

1. Literacy Rate (Education): This measures the education level within a population and is included in the PQLI.

 

2. Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) (Living Standards): This measures the number of infants who die before reaching one year of age, reflecting living conditions and healthcare quality. It is included in the PQLI.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Life Expectancy at Birth: This is not included in the PQLI; instead, PQLI considers life expectancy at age one.

 

4. Income per Capita: This is not part of the PQLI; income measurements are used in the Human Development Index (HDI) but not in PQLI.

 

Thus, only the literacy rate and infant mortality rate are included in the PQLI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PQLI measures the quality of life based on literacy rate, infant mortality rate, and life expectancy at age one, excluding income and life expectancy at birth.

 

Remember – PQLI range – 0 – 100 (India - 65)

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the given image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic osteomyelitis

 

The provided CT scan image shows significant periosteal thickening and sclerosis within the diaphysis of the bone, accompanied by central lucency. These radiological features are characteristic of chronic osteomyelitis. Chronic osteomyelitis is a long-standing infection of the bone, leading to extensive periosteal reaction, sclerosis, and central areas of bone destruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ewing sarcoma: Typically presents with a large soft tissue mass and periosteal reaction. The symmetrical soft tissue in the image makes this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma: Usually arises in the metaphysis, with characteristic sunburst periosteal reaction and periosteal lifting, not observed in this diaphyseal lesion.

 

Option D. Fracture: Would present with a distinct fracture line, which is not visible in the image provided. The periosteal reaction and sclerosis are also not typical for a simple fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic osteomyelitis is characterized by periosteal thickening, sclerosis, and central lucency within the bone, which are key diagnostic features visible on imaging.

questions.text:
In haemolytic anaemia, which of the following is correct? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Urobilinogen is high
  2. Serum conjugated bilirubin is elevated
  3. Serum transaminases are increased
  4. Indirect van den Bergh reaction is positive
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 4

 

In haemolytic anaemia, there is increased destruction of red blood cells leading to elevated unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin. This results in:

 

1. Urobilinogen is high: Increased urobilinogen in urine due to normal enterohepatic circulation

 

4. Indirect van den Bergh reaction is positive: Positive indirect van den Bergh reaction due to elevated unconjugated bilirubin

 

These findings are characteristic of haemolytic anaemia and help differentiate it from other causes of jaundice.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Serum conjugated bilirubin is elevated: Incorrect, as conjugated bilirubin elevation is typically seen in obstructive jaundice or hepatic diseases, not in haemolytic anaemia

 

3. Serum transaminases are increased: Incorrect, as elevated transaminases indicate liver cell damage, which is not a feature of haemolytic anaemia

 

Educational Objective:

 

Haemolytic anaemia is characterized by:

 

  • Increased urobilinogen in urine
  • Elevated unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin
  • Positive indirect van den Bergh reaction
  • Normal enterohepatic circulation
